prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Once actions are transferred, the transferee court has sole authority over the pretrial proceedings. Review of the transferee court's decisions is obtained by appeal to or writ from the court of appeals for the circuit having jurisdiction over the transferee court.[1] In limited circumstances, review may be achieved from other courts of appeals.

In one case, the D.C. Circuit exercised jurisdiction over an appeal taken in an action that had been transferred to the Southern District of Texas.[2] The case involved the imposition of sanctions for contempt against a nonparty witness at a deposition being taken in the federal district. The court's analysis of the issues in this case provides useful insight into the powers of the transferee judge.

The court reiterated the traditional rule requiring appeal to the circuit normally having jurisdiction over the transferee court.[3] The court also looked to the established rule that only a judge in the district where a deposition is being taken can impose the contempt sanction against a nonparty witness.[4] The court also recognized that the transferee court exercises jurisdiction over depositions pending in other districts not as judge of his or her own court, but as a judge of the district where the deposition is being taken. The statute providing for the Panel, 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(b), grants authority to the transferee judge to supervise depositions in other districts, and the court concluded when the transferee judge exercises this second type of power, he or she does so as a judge sitting in the district where the deposition is being taken and that appeal was therefore proper to the circuit court having jurisdiction over the other judges in that district.[5]

The authority of the appellate court reviewing decisions of the transferee court is not unlimited. The appellate court cannot, for example, order remand of an action as part of its review. The power to order remand lies only with the Panel, and the appellate court cannot properly order remand.[6]

Multidistrict litigation generally presents challenges for applying traditional rules of appellate review, particularly the issue of finality. Cases are centralized before a single judge for coordinated pretrial proceedings, but the cases retain many of their individual characteristics, including the fact that they will be remanded to the district where they were filed upon the completion of pretrial proceedings. Some appellate courts have found that they lack jurisdiction over an appeal from an order in a single coordinated case even if the order decides every issue as to every party in that case.[7] The Supreme Court has resolved the uncertainty over this issue in a 2015 decision in a case arising from the LIBOR cases, a MDL docket.[8] The Court granted cert to resolve the question of whether an appeal of right could be taken where the court dismissed all of the claims in several individual actions and entered a judgment of dismissal, but other cases remained as part of the MDL docket because they included claims not resolved the by the motion. The Court held that nothing remained to be litigated in the dismissed cases, and that the litigants had no interest in the ongoing MDL proceedings. The court concluded, quoting section 9:21 of the Manual,

The sensible solution to the appeal-clock trigger is evident: When the transferee court overseeing pretrial proceedings in multidistrict litigation grants a defendant's dispositive motion ‘on all issues in some transferred cases, [those cases] become immediately appealable … while cases where other issues remain would not be appealable at that time.’[9]

Aside from questions of finality, the special challenges of case management presented in handling cases in the transferee court have resulted in application of especially deferential review of these cases. The review may still be for abuse of discretion, but that discretion is viewed as particularly broad in the MDL context.[10] One court has observed the need for this deference as: “District judges must have authority to manage their dockets, especially during massive litigation such as this [MDL], and we owe deference to their decisions whether and how to enforce the deadlines they impose.”[11]

It is well established that the Panel does not exercise any appellate review function. The Panel does not review decisions of the transferee court nor those of the transferor court.[12] Similarly, the Panel does not direct any manner of the handling of cases by transferee or transferor judges.[13] The Panel has encouraged transferee courts to use the Manual for Complex Litigation to manage multidistrict cases[14] but has generally steered far clear of suggesting to the transferee court how to manage the cases.[15] The Panel has also consistently refused to presume that the transferee court would handle a case in any certain way as an argument against transfer.[16]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
